item.title: 10 Tips for Writing Better Tests
item.description: #1 - Think documentation Your company wiki can be outdated. Tests can't. Everybody wants good and well-written documentation. Unfortunately, it's hard to keep it up to date. I believe tests can replace, somehow, a part of the documentation. Tests‚Ä¶
item.content:encoded:
#1 - Think documentation

Your company wiki can be outdated. Tests can‚Äôt.

Everybody wants good and well-written documentation. Unfortunately, it‚Äôs hard to keep it up to date. I believe tests can replace, somehow, a part of the documentation. Tests provide a good description of how your application should behave.

Let me show you an example I could write:

// Shop.spec.js
it('should show list of product', () => {
  /* ... */
})
it('should hide non-available products', () => {
  /* ... */
})
it('should display a discount label when available', () => {
  /* ... */
})
it('should paginate when > 10 products', () => {
  /* ... */
})

Just by reading the name of the name of the file and the 4 descriptions, I already know what is this functionality and some business rules.

Also, if the ‚Äúshould hide non-available products‚Äù test breaks, I know exactly where to start my investigations.

#2 - Isolate your tests

To better organise your test file, you can group related assertions under the same test (= the same it()/test()). Try to keep your reasonably small. Smaller tests are easier to understand and easier to maintain.

Sometimes, we need to test a full process. Like a payment flow where you have a few different steps (i.e. payment info > user address > confirmation).

If you hesitate between creating one big test vs one test per step, where ‚Äústep 2‚Äù depends on ‚Äústep 1‚Äù, go for the first option. It‚Äôs OK to have some longer tests.

Sharing a state between tests is a bad idea. They‚Äôre hard to debug and soon or later, you will face weird issues caused by side effects. Always keep your tests isolated. Tests should not depend on each other.

#3 - Keep it flat

I tend not to write any condition (if/else/‚Ä¶) in my tests. If your test has an if condition, maybe you are testing 2 different things. Which means, your test may have too many responsibilities.

Remember the S of SOLID (S = Single-responsibility Principle). If it makes the coffee, toast your bread and fetch the forecast‚Ä¶ there might be something wrong.

#4 - Only mock what you can‚Äôt control

Every time we mock, we diverge from the real world scenario.

For this reason, you should avoid them as much as possible. But, sometimes we have no other option but to use it. Here are the only exceptions:

  • for external API calls (HTTP GET/POST/‚Ä¶);
  • for browsers API (local/session storage, navigator‚Ä¶);
  • ‚Ä¶ and time-based stuff (date, random methods‚Ä¶).

Talking about time, if you‚Äôre testing a timer, don‚Äôt block the pipeline for the x seconds required by the timer. Mock the clock!

#5 - Avoid assertion in loops (forEach/‚Ä¶)

A common error is to test a list in a loop.

Example: I want to test a page that loads 30 items.

import fakeDataProducts from '../fixtures'

it('should shows list of product', async () => {
  const wrapper = await render(ProductList)
  fakeDataProducts.products.forEach(product => {
    expect(wrapper.find(product.name)).toBeInTheDocument()
  })
})

What‚Äôs wrong here?

  • Too many assertions: multiple assertions can potentially slow down the execution of the test suite.
  • Non-valuable tests: asserting the presence of one item can be a good idea. But, testing the presence of each item doesn‚Äôt seem to add much value.

Exception: When each element of the array represents a different use case.

#6 - Test your app in the same way as a user will use it

The more your tests resemble the way your software is used, the more confidence they can give you.
‚Äî Kent C. Dodds

Let say you want to login on your favourite social network. You fill your username and your password. And after that: do you search in the DOM for the button with id="login-form-btn"? or do you click on the button called ‚ÄúLog In‚Äù? Why do you test differently?

If the keyword ‚ÄúLog In‚Äù is already present on the page, you can query your item with accessibility attribute (i.e. aria-label, ‚Ä¶). In this way, you will enforce your component accessibility.

#7 - Favour integration tests

You probably read Martin Fowler‚Äôs blog talking about the Testing Pyramid. In a nutshell, this blog said: write a lot of unit tests (fast and cheap), some integration tests and a few end-to-end tests (slow and expensive).

But, this post was written in 2012. 8 years ago! I believe we play a different game today with different rules too.

Unit testing a Redux/Vuex store gives me zero confidence. I‚Äôve done it in the past. Many times‚Ä¶ but, the number of bugs haven‚Äôt changed. Why? Because bugs and regressions are generally not in small pieces of code. We found them at a higher level.


(Unit vs. Integration tests)

Integration tests are more expensive than unit tests. But, it‚Äôs worth the trouble.

#8 - Avoid implementation detail

Let‚Äôs say you want to test a ‚Äúlike button‚Äù. You might be tempted to do something like this:

const wrapper = mount(<LikeButton />)
wrapper.find('Like').simulate('click')
expect(wrapper.state().liked).toBe(true)

What‚Äôs wrong here?

  • False positives: (aka false alarm) It looks like an error but it‚Äôs not.
    Let say, you want to refactor the component. By refactoring, I mean changing the implementation, not in the behaviour or the contract (props, events‚Ä¶). Otherwise, it‚Äôs not a refactor.
    If you rename liked to isLiked, the test will fail. And it should not. We write tests to fail when something goes wrong. Nobody cares about a variable name! But, it‚Äôs a different story when it comes to behaviour. Only test what matters!

  • False negatives: (test pass but it shouldn‚Äôt)
    Instead of verifying the output, we check the internals. We can‚Äôt be sure the output still works as expected. This scenario can happen because we did not test the app in the same way as your final user will. In other words, our users and other devs who are going to use this component don‚Äôt really care about the magic inside the component.

To avoid implementation detail, treat your component as a black box: only test the inputs and the outputs.

The same test, without implementation detail could be:

const spy = jest.fn()
const wrapper = mount(<LikeButton onClick={spy}/>)
wrapper.find('Like').simulate('click')

expect(wrapper.prop('aria-label').toEqual('liked')
expect(spy.mock.calls[0][0]).toBe(true)

#9 - Always green

I remember when I joined a company a few years ago. On Day One, I couldn‚Äôt start the application. After investigations, it turns out someone had forgotten a ; in a SQL file and pushed it to master. The application was broken because of a god damn semicolon. With basic tooling, those kinds of problems should never happen.

If you ask a dev to run the run manually the test before opening a pull request, it‚Äôs not gonna work. Humans are fallible. Plus, this is a dumb job. Better delegate this job to a robot, they are cheap and never lie. Automated jobs will ensure your tests are always green.

Because I don‚Äôt even trust myself, all of my side projects have CI enabled by default. The only way for me to merge my own code is to open a pull request and get a green build.

#10 - Write tests for confidence, not for metrics

‚ÄúWhen a measure becomes a target, it ceases to be a good measure‚Äù
Ôºç Goodhart‚Äôs law

I see a lot of people writing Coverage-Driven Test‚Ñ¢Ô∏è. Because their manager asked to, or because they want to show off with a ‚Äú100% code coverage‚Äù on the GitHub repository.

In my opinion, this is a really bad idea. And for a few reasons:

  • Code covered does not necessarily mean code tested;
  • High code coverage gives the illusion of quality. But, you can have a high percentage with irrelevant tests that does nothing except bumping the score (cf. implementation detail);
  • Dev doesn‚Äôt write tests for being confident but to satisfy a metric.

This last point is very important. By taking the problem on the wrong side, we forgot why we write tests. We should all write tests for confidence. Confidence for shipping code that works as described and also confidence that the behaviour will remain unchanged 6 months later when you or a colleague will work on this part of the application.

Not all code needs tests. Expecting the same amount of test in your App hidden settings and in the payment page is absolute nonsense. Writing tests is an investment. If tests don‚Äôt provide any visible ROI (Return On Investment), skip them. Except, if you‚Äôre working on a library (open source or not).

Thanks for reading this article ü§ò

You can leave a message on the section below if you think I forgot an important point‚Ä¶ or if you just want to insult me :)

This post was the first one of my ‚Äútesting series‚Äù. In the next weeks/months, I plan to talk about code coverage, good practices in Vue.js testing and also how to test JAMstack/Gatsby applications.

item.title: How to generate social share images with Gatsby
item.description: TL;DR: Generating share images can be done in 3 steps: create a preview page; screenshot it (with Puppeteer); add the image in the page's metatags. When you spend hours writing a blog post, you want it to stand out, not to be lost in a feed. That's‚Ä¶
item.content:encoded:
TL;DR: Generating share images can be done in 3 steps:

  1. create a preview page;
  2. screenshot it (with Puppeteer);
  3. add the image in the page‚Äôs metatags.

When you spend hours writing a blog post, you want it to stand out, not to be lost in a feed. That‚Äôs why having a social share image attached to your blog post is crucial. People are drawn to visual content. Our brains respond very quick to images in comparison to plain text.

The idea behind this post is to show you how to generate preview images like this for your Gatsby.js website.

Social share images are used by social media (Twitter/Facebook/LinkedIn‚Ä¶) and also some conversational applications (Slack/Telegram/WhatsApp/‚Ä¶).

Before we start, keep in mind that Gatsby is static website generator. We can‚Äôt generate images ‚Äúon the fly‚Äù as we do with other dynamic languages (i.e. PHP‚Ä¶).

Step 1: create the preview page

The preview page is meant to be screenshotted and only screenshotted!

Your blog post page should be generated with something like createPage(). So, we are going to duplicate this statement to create the preview page.

// gatsby-node.js
posts.forEach((post, index, posts) => {
  // create the blog post page
  createPage({
    path: post.node.frontmatter.slug,
    component: require.resolve('./src/templates/blog-post.js'),
    context: {
      slug: post.node.frontmatter.slug
    },
  })

  // create the blogpost page preview
  createPage({    path: `${post.node.frontmatter.slug}/image_tw`,    component: require.resolve('./src/templates/blog-post-share-image.js'),    context: {      slug: post.node.frontmatter.slug,    },  })
})

üí°How to disable this page in production?

I guess you don‚Äôt want to see this page is production right? If you wrap the createPage in the following ‚Äúif condition‚Äù. So, the page will be only accessible with gatsby develop command.

if (process.env.gatsby_executing_command.includes('develop')) {
  createPage({
    // ...
  })
}

Then, we need to create the blog-post-share-image.js. In the GraphQL query, fetch fields you want to use (post title, time to read‚Ä¶). And render everything in a rectangle (i.e. 440 x 220 pixels).

If you want, here‚Äôs the template I use for maxpou.fr. Now, use your HTML/CSS skill to make the nicest preview üí™.

After that, the preview should be accessible at http://localhost:8000/your-article-slug/image_share.

Step 2: screenshot the preview

To take a screenshot, I use Puppeteer. Here‚Äôs a part of the script I am using to take a screenshot:

// scripts/generatePostPreviewImages.js
// full script available here:
// https://github.com/maxpou/gatsby-starter-morning-dew/blob/master/scripts/generatePostPreviewImages.js

// #!/usr/bin/env node
const puppeteer = require('puppeteer')

const takeScreenshot = async (url, destination) => {
  const browser = await puppeteer.launch()
  const page = await browser.newPage()
  await page.goto(url)
  await page.screenshot({
    path: destination,
    clip: {
      x: 0,
      y: 0,
      width: 440,
      height: 220,
    },
  })

  await browser.close()
}

const main = async () => {
  const files = getArticleFiles()

  for (let i = 0; i < files.length; i++) {
    const file = files[i]
    const destinationFile = join(file.directory, `${file.slug}-share.png`)

    // (existsSync check if the file already exist)
    if (!existsSync(destinationFile)) {
      await takeScreenshot(`${baseUrl}${file.slug}/image_share`, destinationFile)
      console.log(`Created ${destinationFile}`)
    }
  }
}

main()

‚Ä¶and in the package.json, make the script available as a command.

{
  "scripts": {
    /* ... */
    "generatePostPreviewImages": "./scripts/generatePostPreviewImages.js"
  }
}

We are now ready to create the picture! To generate the preview image, open 2 terminals:

  • Terminal 1: npm run gatsby develop;
  • Terminal 2: npm run generatePostPreviewImages.

You should have generated some preview images (1 per blog post). The script above put the image directly in the blog post folder.

Step 3: integrate the picture in the DOM

The social image is now generated. Before you add it in the HTML‚Äôs body, don‚Äôt forget to link the image with the blog post.

# ./my-blog-post.md
---
title: "How to generate social share images with Gatsby"
slug: generate-social-image-share-with-gatsby
cover: ./cover.png
# links preview image
imageShare: ./git-under-the-hood-share.png---

Your blog post content

When you render your blog post, you can add the image generated in an SEO component.

class BlogPostTemplate extends React.Component {
  render() {
    const post = this.props.data.post

    return (
      <Layout>
        <SEO
          imageShare={post.frontmatter.imageShare.publicURL}          /* other: title, description, url... */
        />

        <Wrapper>
          <Article post={post} />
        </Wrapper>

      </Layout>
    )
  }
}

The SEO component purpose is to manage all the meta-information located in the page‚Äôs <head>. If you don‚Äôt have this component, you can get some inspiration from the Gatsby-starter-blog. Also, feel free to copy/paste the code I wrote for my website.

At the end, you should have something similar in your HTML‚Äôs body:

<!-- Open Graph meta tags -->
<meta property="og:url" content="https://www.maxpou.fr/super-cool-blog" />
<meta property="og:type" content="article" />
<meta property="og:title" content="My super-cool blog post | maxpou.fr" />
<meta property="og:description" content="This is my very cool blog post description!" />
<meta property="og:image" content="https://www.maxpou.fr/path/to/image/generated.png" />

<!-- Twitter Card Tags -->
<meta name="twitter:card" content="summary_large_image" />
<meta name="twitter:creator" content="_maxpou" />
<meta name="twitter:title" content="My super-cool blog post | gatsby-starter-morning-dew" />
<meta name="twitter:description" content="This is my very cool blog post description!" />
<meta name="twitter:image" content="https://www.maxpou.fr/path/to/image/generated.png" />

and‚Ä¶ tadaa it should works üéâ

Conclusion

If you want to check your metatags, you can use Twitter cards Validator. To test the Open Graph tags, I usually send a message to myself on Slack.

That‚Äôs it for today! I hope this post will help you to generate your social images share. I copied all examples from my Gatsby starter/theme: gatsby-starter-morning-dew.

item.content:encoded:
Disclaimer: I mostly wrote this blog post for myself. Writing my Year in review helps me to celebrate my biggest wins, see what was wrong and define goals for the upcoming year.

üë®‚Äçüíª Work

  • I am still working as a Sr Frontend Engineer at VSware where I‚Äôm building software for education.
  • On a day to day, I work with:
    • A (too?) big Vue.js application. I don‚Äôt touch the backend (in Java).
    • Frontend Infrastructure: with interesting problems like scaling monorepo, continuous deployment/integration‚Ä¶
    • Vue.js Testing. I converted a few colleagues to Testing-library üéâ
    • Interesting features to develop. For example, I created a sort of Google Calendar from scratch.
  • I‚Äôm still 100% remote and the most of my colleagues are in the same office in Ireland. In 2019, I spent a lot of time in Asia.
    • timezone diff is great in the morning because I can work without being polluted by Slack;
    • timezone diff can be tough‚Ä¶ when I was in Bali (+8h), I had to end meetings at 1 AM üò¨
    • timezone diff sometimes pushed me to do overwork.

Overall, I üíô working remotely.

üë®üèº‚Äçüî¨ Side projects

  • This year was special because I gave zero talks! I‚Äôm thinking about removing ‚ÄúPublic speaker‚Äù in my twitter bio üòÑ
  • I worked on my Gatsby theme/starter gatsby-starter-morning-dew. This project passed 100+ ‚≠êÔ∏è on GitHub. Git/CI pipeline is nearly perfect to me. Overall, I‚Äôm super proud of what I‚Äôve done for this project.

‚úçÔ∏è Blog

  • Last year, I published 7 posts, 3 posts about git! Promise, I will be more diverse in 2020!
  • 34k users and 62.5k page views on maxpou.fr. This is more or less the same numbers as last year.
  • Cross-posted a few on dev.to (2,465 reactions - 85,568 Total Post Views).
  • My post Git: Cheat Sheet is the 25th most viewed post on Dev.to for 2019. And 30th all time ü§©

üò•Failures: online courses

At the beginning of 2019, I get contacted by a famous platform to do some online courses about Vue.js Testing. I already gave a few training in the past and I setup twice a testing strategies for Vue.js application. At first glance, it looked like an easy way to get money and improve my personal branding. But, recording courses is not like giving a talk. Every time you make a mistake or a car start horning on the street, you have to start over. Additionally, I also underestimated the required equipment to record my voice and my screen. I‚Äôm travelling with only one backpack, there‚Äôs no room in my bag for a decent microphone/2nd screen. Sadly, I had to admit that the job wasn‚Äôt for me and I resigned.

üßó‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è Sport

Since I‚Äôm 8, I go every year in Spain to do Canyoning. In the beginning, it was with my parents. Now my cousin and I took a dozen friends and we play the role of guide.

This year was a consecration for us. We did the most difficult canyon of the region: Las Gorgas Negras. A ~12h long journey. We woke up at 5 AM, started the approach to the canyon (~3h) then we were all the time in the water until our camping (~9h). As you might guess, it was very exhausting!
The good thing is, we managed to take our camping at the end of the canyon. So, straight after the canyon, we went to the camping‚Äôs bar. I think it‚Äôs the first time I drank a beer in a wetsuit üòÖ

‚úàÔ∏è Travels

This year I travelled a LOT, especially in Asia. This continent was completely new for me. And I loved it.

This year, I lived in:

  • Singapore.
  • Bali (Indonesia): Canggu, Ubud and Gili Air. I also visited the whole island when my friends went to visit me
  • Malaysia: Kuala Lumpur, Langkawi and Penang (George Town)
  • Thailand: Bangkok and Chiang Mai
  • Vietnam: Ho Chi Minh City (Saigon)

I also went to Rodellar (Sierra de Guara, Spain), but it was for holidays.

‚ú® Random stuff

Lantern Festival in Chiang Mai, Thailand

  • üìñRead 2 books. Looks ridiculous but I did ‚Äúx2‚Äù regarding 2018!
  • üèÉ‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏èSport. Not as much as I wanted but I started to run.
  • üëÆüèª‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏èI gave my first bribe. Almost two actually but, I didn‚Äôt stop üôä
  • üç≤Eating Indian food or a Thai curry for breakfast seems normal now;
  • üíÜ‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏èHad a LOT of massage (mostly in Bali);
  • ü§ùMet cool persons from the nomad/maker community
  • üò∑Had to wear a pollution mask during Haze in Malaysia
  • üçªGot drunk at 11 AM in a plane with a Hells Angels member
  • üèÆSaw the Lantern Festival in Chiang Mai, Thailand
  • üéÇCelebrated my 1st year as a Digital Nomad
  • üéÇCelebrated my 30 with my friends in France. I‚Äôm getting old üòÅ

Previous ‚Äúhigh-level goals‚Äù

I copy/paste my previous goals. After reflection, I found some of them a little bit BS since they‚Äôre not measurable.

  • ‚úÖBe able to work with my colleagues in Ireland ~ It was not easy to deal with timezone but I think I managed to do it :)

  • ‚úÖWrite my 2019 year in review on time!

‚Ä¶and 100 days before 2020, I set up additional goals

  • ‚ùåRead 2 books ~ I read only one.
  • ‚úÖExplore Malaysian Islands
  • ‚úÖStop overworking

High-level 2020 goals

  • [Travel] Discover new countries ~ thinking about Hungary üá≠üá∫ and Japan üáØüáµ;
  • [Travel] Be more organised when it comes to my travels;
  • [Life] Stay remote / nomad;
  • [Life] Continue to meet nomads when I travel;
  • [Life] Better invest my money;

item.title: Git: Cheat Sheet (advanced)
item.description: If you find git confusing, I created this little cheat sheet! Please, note that I voluntarily skipped the basic commands like git commit , git pull/push ... This cheat sheet is intended for advanced usage of git. üß≠ Navigation - Go to the previous‚Ä¶
item.content:encoded:
If you find git confusing, I created this little cheat sheet! Please, note that I voluntarily skipped the basic commands like git commit, git pull/push‚Ä¶ This cheat sheet is intended for advanced usage of git.

üß≠ Navigation - Go to the previous branch

git checkout -

üîç Get the history

# Log in one line
git log --oneline

# Retrieve all commits by message
# Here all commit that contain 'homepage'
git log --all --grep='homepage'

# Retrieve all commit by author
git log --author="Maxence"

üôàOoops #1: I reseted an unwanted commit. How to rollback?

# Get everything you did
git reflog

# then reset to the desired commit (i.e. HEAD@{4})
git reset HEAD@{4}
# ...or...
git reset --hard <commit-sha1>

For more detail about this command, I wrote another post: What‚Äôs happens when you ‚Äògit commit‚Äô.

ü§¶‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏èOoops #2: I mixed-up with my local repo. How to clean it?

git fetch origin
git checkout master
git reset --hard origin/master
# You're now up-to-date with master!

üïµüèª‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏èDifference between my branch and master

git diff master..my-branch

‚úî Custom commits

# Edit last commit
git commit --amend -m "A better message"

# Add something to the last commit without writing message again
git add . && git commit --amend --no-edit

# empty commit - can be useful to re-trigger CI build...
git commit --allow-empty -m "chore: re-trigger build"

If you don‚Äôt know what to put in your commit messages, I wrote a post about conventional commits.

‚ôªÔ∏è Squash commits

Let say I want to rebase the last 3 commits:

  1. git rebase -i HEAD~3
  2. Leave the first ‚Äúpick‚Äù and replace the rest by ‚Äùsquash‚Äù (or ‚Äùs‚Äú)
  3. Tidy up the commit message and save (:wq in vi).

üéØFixup

Let say I want to add something in the commit fed14a4c

git add .

git commit --fixup HEAD~1
# or replace HEAD~1 by the commit hash (fed14a4c)

git rebase -i HEAD~3 --autosquash
# save&quit the file (:wq in VI)

üïπExecute command on each commit when rebasing

For massives features, you might end up with a branch with a few commits inside. And then tests are failing and you want to identify the ‚Äúguilty commit‚Äù. You can use rebase --exec to execute a command on each commit of the history.

# Will run "npm test" command on the last 3 commit ‚ù§Ô∏è
git rebase HEAD~3 --exec "npm run test"

ü¶ãStash

Because it‚Äôs not all about git stash and git stash pop ;)

# save all tracked files
git stash save "your message"

# list your stashes
git stash list

# retrieve stash and delete
git stash apply stash@{1}
git stash drop stash@{1}
# ... or in 1 command
git stash pop stash@{1}

üóë Clean

# remove branches that no longer exist on remote
git fetch -p

# remove all branch that contains "greenkeeper"
git fetch -p && git branch --remote | fgrep greenkeeper | sed 's/^.\{9\}//' | xargs git push origin --delete

üêô GitHub = Git + Hub

I use Hub as a wrapper for git. To enable it you‚Äôve to set hub as an alias for git (alias git='hub').

# Open browser and go to the repository url (GitHub only)
git browse

Other commands are available here.

ü¶Ñ Bonus: my favourite git aliases

alias g='git'
alias glog='git log --oneline --decorate --graph'
alias gst='git status'
alias gp='git push'
alias ga='git add'
alias gc='git commit -v'

# ü§ò
alias yolo='git push --force'

# useful for daily stand-up
git-standup() {
    AUTHOR=${AUTHOR:="`git config user.name`"}

    since=yesterday
    if [[ $(date +%u) == 1 ]] ; then
        since="2 days ago"
    fi

    git log --all --since "$since" --oneline --author="$AUTHOR"
}

And you, what‚Äôs your favourite git command?

item.title: How to mock Date with Jest
item.description: I spent too many hours trying to mock correctly the JavaScript's Date object. I tried a few things I've found on Google... without success. I finally ended up with a kinda handcrafted solution. Every time we mock, we diverge from the real world‚Ä¶
item.content:encoded:
I spent too many hours trying to mock correctly the JavaScript‚Äôs Date object. I tried a few things I‚Äôve found on Google‚Ä¶ without success. I finally ended up with a kinda handcrafted solution.

Every time we mock, we diverge from the real world scenario.

For this reason, I tend not to mock‚Ä¶ but sometimes, there are not many choices. Fortunately, Date is one good exception!

Everybody on the same timezone!

To prevent problems related to timezones (e.g. date formating), you can set node timezone in jest config file. Now you are sure all tests are executed on the same timezone no matter where your colleagues or your CI server are.

// jest.config.js
process.env.TZ = 'GMT'

module.exports = {
  // ...
}

See also: the full list of timezones (column TZ database name)

Mock Date.now

Let‚Äôs say I want to test a dashboard component which tells me ‚Äúhello‚Äù with the date of the day. The lazy way is to only test the Hello part (without the date). Because it changes every day. But you won‚Äôt test the date formatting part.

If you want to, you gonna have to mock Date.now() and put a default one.

// your-test.spec.js

const RealNow = Date.now

beforeAll(() => {
  global.Date.now = jest.fn(() => new Date('2019-04-07T10:20:30Z').getTime())
})

afterAll(() => {
  global.Date.now = RealNow
})

Now in the same file, you can add something like the following:

it('should show a formatted date of today', async () => {
  const dashboard = await Mount(<Dashboard />)
  expect(dashboard).toHaveText('Hi Max, today is 7 April 2019')
})

üí°RealDate store ‚Äúreal‚Äù Date instance, so we can put it back afterwards.

Using Moment.js?

You are probably using the very popular moment.js library. If so, mocking Date.now, will probably not be enough. A workaround is to mock the entire node module.

// <root>/__mocks__/moment.js
const moment = jest.requireActual('moment')

Date.now = () => new Date('2019-04-07T10:20:30Z').getTime()

module.exports = moment

With this solution, you don‚Äôt need beforeAll()/afterAll() listener. This mock will be effective for all tests. And, every time moment() is called, return date will be the same üéâ

Big shout out to Avalander for pointing out some errors. https://dev.to/avalander/comment/ibc7

item.title: What's happens when you `git commit`
item.description: Nowadays, most of our projects use Git as a version control system. It means most of our projects have a .git folder. But, have you ever tried to open it? I tried once... and I closed it within a minute! I've been using Git as a "black box" for‚Ä¶
item.content:encoded:
Nowadays, most of our projects use Git as a version control system. It means most of our projects have a .git folder. But, have you ever tried to open it? I tried once‚Ä¶ and I closed it within a minute!

I‚Äôve been using Git as a ‚Äúblack box‚Äù for years.

Until a year ago. I was tired of using it without knowing how it works under the hood. I finally grabbed the bull by the horns and started to learn it. I read Pro Git and make tons of experiments. I‚Äôve found out that it‚Äôs not as complicated as it looks like!

So, If you:

  • are the guy in the picture above,
  • want to understand what‚Äôs in this .git folder,
  • already ‚Äúlost code with git‚Äù‚Ä¶

‚Ä¶this blog post is for you! üòÉ

Step 1: Git Data Model

To make things more understandable, I will start with a new basic project (2 files: index.js and README.md).

  1. git init
  2. echo "console.log('hi')" >> index.js
  3. echo "# Cool project" >> README.md
  4. git add . && git commit -m "First commit"

Now let‚Äôs see what we have in the .git folder:

$ tree .git/objects

.git/objects
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ 2d
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ 1a41ebd2d32cb426b6d32e61e063f330aa1af8
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ 66
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ 87898e2a0fe2da282efab6b5f7f38b7f788f56
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ c2
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ 43f24fb294ebc954b0a7ee6020589245f78315
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ c3
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ 0500babf488d06033e8d039cbf64be3edbd089
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ info
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ pack

6 directories, 4 files

Git created 4 files. For not ending with thousands of files under the same folder, git automatically truncates the 2 first characters for the folder name. To retrieve one git object, you have to concatenate the folder name + file name.

And because the files are not human-readable, you can use git cat-file <sha-1> -p to see what‚Äôs inside (or use the -t option to get the type). By the way, you can only use the first 8 characters.

Here‚Äôs how the files are linked together:

üí° Git object model has 4 different types:

  • commit: contain the committer, date, message and also the directory tree;
  • tree: reference other trees and/or blobs;
  • blob: store file data;
  • tag: store a commit reference (not addressed in this blog post).

Please note that blobs don‚Äôt store their filename (and location). That‚Äôs one of the reasons why sometimes git lost history when you change file location ;)

ü§îIf you try it locally, expect to have a different hash (different author&date)!

Step 2: Adding a second commit!

Now we want to update index.js and add a second line to the file:

  1. echo "console.log('world')" >> index.js
  2. git add . && git commit -m "Second commit"

We now have 3 more entries:

$ tree .git/objects

.git/objects
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ 11‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ 75e42a41f75f4b25bab53db36d581f72387aa9‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ 2d
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ 1a41ebd2d32cb426b6d32e61e063f330aa1af8
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ 66
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ 87898e2a0fe2da282efab6b5f7f38b7f788f56
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ c2
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ 43f24fb294ebc954b0a7ee6020589245f78315
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ c3
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ 0500babf488d06033e8d039cbf64be3edbd089
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ ee‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ c2cd5e0b771793e03bbd5f8614c567af964a4e‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ fc‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ 512af17ca7ec04be6958047648b32629e4b5a5‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ info
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ pack

9 directories, 7 files

We now have something like this:

üëÄ Something interesting here: Git doesn‚Äôt store diff between files! Thanks to the packfiles (in .git/objects/pack), Git keeps a reasonable place on the disk.

Step 3: Playing with time and f*** up everything ü§¶‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è

In this last step, we are going to add one commit. Then, we will go back in the past to ‚Äúremove this commit‚Äù.

  1. echo "console.log('üòÉ')" >> index.js
  2. git add . && git commit -m "Third commit"

As you might guess now, git created 3 new files. The structure is similar from step 2.

.git/objects
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ 00
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ ee8c50f8d74eaf1d3a4160e9d9c9eb1c683132
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ 09
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ f760de83890e3c363a38e6dc0700b76e782bc1
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ cf
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ 81d6f570911938726cff95b62acbf198fd3510
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ ...

12 directories, 10 files

Now, let‚Äôs pretend we want to go back in the past from 1 commit (git reset HEAD~1 --hard).

‚Ä¶and now you think you fucked up everything and your commit is gone forever. Right? Maybe. Let‚Äôs count how many git objects we have‚Ä¶

$ tree .git/objects

.git/objects
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ ...

12 directories, 10 files

Look: we still have 10 files! Nothing was deleted! Guess what? If I git cat-file cf81d6f570911938726cff95b62acbf198fd3510 -p, I will get the content of index.js at the third commit. üéâ

‚ÄúYou can‚Äôt lose code with git.‚Äù
‚ÄîMe

More seriously, I use git push --force, git rebase and git reset --hard daily and I never lost anything. But, we are human and humans are fallible.

Don‚Äôt worry, if you want to rollback, you don‚Äôt have to go through all those files. There‚Äôs a magic trick!

reflog: the magic wand ‚ú®

If you try to retrieve the history with git log, you will not see the ‚ÄúThird commit‚Äù. But, if you add the additional option -g (for --walk-reflogs), then you‚Äôll see the third commit.

To make it nicer, you can do git log -g --abbrev-commit --pretty=oneline.

This super-useful command has an alias: git reflog ‚ù§Ô∏è

$ git reflog

eec2cd5 (HEAD -> master) HEAD@{0}: reset: moving to HEAD~1
00ee8c5 HEAD@{1}: commit: Third commit
eec2cd5 (HEAD -> master) HEAD@{2}: commit: Second commit
c30500b HEAD@{3}: commit (initial): First commit

(Note: you can get something similar in .git/logs/HEAD)

Now, you have the third commit‚Äôs fingetprint: 00ee8c5. You can now git reset 00ee8c5 --hard to cancel previous reset.

Caveats:

In some cases, git reflog will not help you:

  • when you pull someone else code;
  • when you remove your repo and clone it again;
  • if you‚Äôre looking for a >90 days change (after that git gc clean it up). I don‚Äôt know about you, but, I can‚Äôt remember what I did ~1 month ago. So, 3 months should be more than enough üòâ

Also, if you use git commit like you ctrl + s, you might be easily lost. I‚Äôm sorry, but, I can‚Äôt do anything for you, except recommending you to read my post about the conventional commits. In my opinion, it‚Äôs the cleanest way to use git.

Wrapping up ~ TL;DR

  • there are 4 different types of git objects: commit, tree, blob and tag.
  • blobs don‚Äôt know their name (it‚Äôs the reason why you lose history during a move).
  • Git doesn‚Äôt store diffs.
  • committed code cannot be lost. git reflog can help you.

That‚Äôs it for today!

item.title: Digital Nomad: the Golden Ticket?
item.description: Last October, I joined the so-called Digital Nomad movement. If you have never heard about it, I am combining remote working with travelling. I really like this lifestyle because it gives me a lot of freedom and flexibility. However, when I get back‚Ä¶
item.content:encoded:
Last October, I joined the so-called Digital Nomad movement. If you have never heard about it, I am combining remote working with travelling. I really like this lifestyle because it gives me a lot of freedom and flexibility.

However, when I get back home or when I read articles on the internet, I realised that my life is far from what people think.

The idea behind this blog post is to debunk some myths about the digital nomad movement.

Myth #1: You work from the beach

Let‚Äôs start from the beginning. When you Google the term ‚ÄúDigital Nomad‚Äù, you will get this:

It looks fantastic right?

Sorry, I have to stop you right now. This is complete bullshit and most of these pictures do not represent the real life of a digital nomad.

Look. The first posture is probably OK for an occasional usage of a laptop. But if you take the habit to work like this, get prepared to end up with RSI/back pain/etc.
Another thing: the brightness. If in the middle of the summer you can‚Äôt see your smartphone, don‚Äôt expect to see your laptop screen in the middle of the beach. And I‚Äôm not gonna talk about the heat generated by the sun on your MacBook, neither the sand on a ~1.500 USD laptop‚Ä¶ or sunglasses usage to see a screen (spoiler: you can‚Äôt see anything)!

Thanks to social media, some self-obsessed pseudo-influencers try to sell you a dream‚Ä¶ a dream that they don‚Äôt even live!

As you can see, I don‚Äôt have a lot of sympathy for people who fake their life ;)

Myth #2: You must be rich

Let‚Äôs talk a minute about money, even if it‚Äôs a controversial topic. Because, it‚Äôs something I heard a lot, and I think there are a few misconceptions.

You don‚Äôt need to be rich to live where most people spend their dreamed holidays.

The most common destinations for nomad are actually quite cheap to live. For example, in Bali (Indonesia) you can easily live with $1.300/month. In Chiang Mai (in Thailand), you can live with $900/month‚Ä¶

How much does it cost to live in NYC, Paris or London?

Choose your destination according to your wallet. I‚Äôve met on the road persons who make between less than 15k to a 6 digits yearly income salary.

Myth #3: You can work from wherever you want

I personally consider every place in the globe with a chair, a table and a decent WiFi as a potential office.

But, there are laws. What I want is not necessarily what I can get. The vast majority of nomadster countries on tourist visas. Which means, you are supposed to be on holiday. In other words: you are legally NOT authorized to work.

If you are working for a foreign company and your job has nothing to do with the country in which you are, it‚Äôs okay (but still illegal). But it‚Äôs another story if you are a travel blogger, english teacher‚Ä¶

And trust me, getting problems with immigration is the last thing you want!

Myth #4: You are constantly travelling

When you have the freedom to be wherever you want, you might be tempted to change city as often as you change your underwear. That more or less what I did at the beginning.

A few weeks ago, I faced something I never had before. I landed in Ho-Chi-Minh City (Vietnam) for the very first time. When I arrived at my apartment, I felt really bad. After a short introspection, I realized that in less than 60 days, I visited 4 countries and 6 cities. I was like Bill Murray in Lost in Translation: completely lost.

Moving too fast is the best way to get a ‚Äúnomadic burnout‚Äù. It happens when you travel too fast. Connecting with people, learning the local culture, facing language/culture barriers, trying not to get scam‚Ä¶ is very exhausting.

Most of the nomad I know slow travel. They use to stay -at least- 2 or 3 months in each place.

Myth #5: You won the Golden Ticket

‚Ä¶ I also heard ‚Äúyou are living the perfect life!‚Äú.

Don‚Äôt get me wrong. I am not here to complain. I‚Äôm not saying I am not enjoying my life. No. I love it.

But, please: don‚Äôt be naive! Every situation comes with its upsides and downsides. In this post, I mostly focus on some cliches related to this lifestyle. There are also a few others downsides I didn‚Äôt mention like:

  • Mental health issues: another underrepresented but important topic. Mostly because it‚Äôs always better for our ego to post a picture on the beach rather than talking about our problems. When you live on a paradisiac island, people think you can‚Äôt complain and you become more isolated.
    If you want to read more, Tim Grassin wrote this awesome post.

  • Loneliness: Let‚Äôs be honest: dealing with loneliness is one of the hardest parts of being a digital nomad. It‚Äôs a constant fight. You meet new people on Meetup/Facebook/Tinder/‚Ä¶ and a month after, you go separate ways.
    Building connections becomes harder when you grow up. It‚Äôs even more when you‚Äôre moving every few months. By the way, it‚Äôs also the reason why I‚Äôm always moving to cities with an existent digital nomad scene.

  • Remote working. Being a part-time remote is challenging. But, 100% remote is another level. It requires a lot of discipline. When I switched to 100% remote, I realised how I underestimate this aspect. You can‚Äôt postpone a meeting because you‚Äôre not in the office today (and you will be next week), you don‚Äôt know if your colleague is joking or not, overworking, managing interruptions, communication issues, etc.
    Remote working requires hustle and grit.

Tips: Always double-check your environment before turning on your webcam üòâ

  • Administrative nightmares: I‚Äôm French working for an Irish company, I own an Irish Phone number and I spend most of my time in South-East Asia living in short term accommodations (changing once or twice a month).
    You can‚Äôt imagine how many problems I faced with web forms üòÑ. Also, forgetting a wallet in a taxi or losing my phone (linked to my bank) because I got drunk last night can lead to serious problems.

  • Timezone hell: The vast majority of my colleagues work in Ireland. Right now, I‚Äôm in Thailand, ahead of 6 hours (7 in winter). When my colleagues start their workday, mine is about to end. But it could be worse. I‚Äôve met people working with 12h diff!

  • And also: unreliable WiFi, power outage, taxes, health insurance, etc.

Sum up

I didn‚Äôt win THE golden ticket, I won MY golden ticket.

Despite all these downsides, I really like this lifestyle. It completely fits me and I think it worth the trouble. Having the freedom to work and travel is an incredible privilege.

I wouldn‚Äôt go back to a normal sedentary life‚Ä¶ for now üòâ

(This is an article posted to my blog at maxpou.fr. You can read it online by clicking here.)

item.title: Two months in Canggu as a Digital Nomad
item.description: After spending a month in Lisbon and another one in Spain, I decided to start 2019 with a continent I never explored before: Asia. And more precisely: in Bali, a small island in Indonesia. If you check on Nomad List , Canggu is the first destination‚Ä¶
item.content:encoded:
After spending a month in Lisbon and another one in Spain, I decided to start 2019 with a continent I never explored before: Asia. And more precisely: in Bali, a small island in Indonesia.
If you check on Nomad List, Canggu is the first destination for digital nomad. I was intrigued and I decided to check it out for myself‚Ä¶ and I love it!

If you‚Äôre intrigued by the hype around Canggu or if you plan to move to there, I wrote this blog post for you. I also wrote this blog post after more than 2 months in Bali. In the beginning, I planned to stay only a month there. I‚Äôm finally going to stay three!

Visa

Disclaimer: I‚Äôm not a visa expert. I‚Äôm talking here about ‚Äúholidays visa‚Äù - which means: you‚Äôre supposed to be on holidays and not working with/in Indonesia.

There‚Äôre different options on the table:

  • < 30 days - VISA Exemption - You don‚Äôt need a visa.
  • Between 30 and 60 days - Visa On Arrival (VOA) - When you arrive at the airport, you‚Äôve to pay $35 and you can stay 30 days in the country. If you need, you can extend it with 30 more days. If you don‚Äôt like administrative things like me, I recommend you to do your extension with an agent (i.e. Visa4Bali).

  • 60 days - Social Visa - Allows you to stay in the country for 6 months. But, you can‚Äôt leave the country.

When I arrived, I took a VOA and I extended it. The thing is, I wanted to stay for 3 months in Bali. So, I‚Äôve to leave the country (‚ÄúVisa Run‚Äù). Thanks to AirAsia, you can get a return ticket from Singapore or Kuala Lumpur for nearly 50‚Ç¨. I picked Kuala Lumpur! I‚Äôm now in my 3rd month in Bali. Because I‚Äôm gonna stay 27 days in Bali, I didn‚Äôt need to pay for a VOA visa.

Accommodation

Because I don‚Äôt have (and I don‚Äôt want to have) scooter, I had to find something in the middle of Canggu. Thanks to Booking.com, I‚Äôve found a homestay for ~21‚Ç¨/night. With this price, I had a big room (maybe too big) with a private bathroom, a simple breakfast and a swimming pool. Also, my room was cleaned -almost- every day. Good point, I was in a walking distance (10mins) from the Dojo (coworking space) and the beach.

Internet

Almost all coffee/restaurants/accommodations have a WIFI to share. Unfortunately, it‚Äôs very flaky and not 100% reliable! That‚Äôs why I recommend you to get a local SIM Cards. In Indonesia, it‚Äôs cheap and ludicrously straightforward: you pay, you put the SIM in the phone and‚Ä¶ tadaa üéâit‚Äôs working! (I‚Äôd love to get something as simple as this in France!). As far as I know, Telkomsel is the best provider. You can buy SIM cards from everywhere (avoid the airport, you gonna pay 10x the normal price). With this provider, I‚Äôm getting +/- 23MBS. I paid 100k (6.2e) for 12Gb of data.

Also, talking about internet, something you have to know. Freedom of speech doesn‚Äôt exist in Indonesia. A lot of websites are blocked by ISP: Reddit, torrents, porn, video game and Facebook (I‚Äôm looking at you Telkomsel). Using a VPN is strongly recommended.

Coworking spaces

Dojo is one of the most famous coworking space in Bali. I really liked the ‚Äúmaker‚Äù atmosphere in this place. A lot of people are bootstrapping their own product/startup. It was globally very inspiring. From a social aspect, people are really open-minded and making new friends is super easy. Also, Dojo organises a LOT of events (marketing, language exchange, public speaking course, developer, personal development‚Ä¶). Like, one per day!
Every Friday, you have the Beach and Beers, which is a great event to meet new people! If I had to find thee cons, I‚Äôd say the price. I‚Äôve found the place a bit overpriced (2.900.000IDR/180‚Ç¨ for 1 month unlimited). Because I pay coworking spaces with my own money, I pick a 100h/month option (1.800.000IDR/112‚Ç¨).

If you‚Äôre on a tight budget, you can also work from cafes. It‚Äôs common here and they all have Wifi!

When I will come back to Canggu, I want to give a try to the second co-working pace in Canggu: Outpost.

Food

üí• Booom! üí•
For people who like to eat (like me üòâ), you found your place! The food scene in Bali is amazing. Because I didn‚Äôt have a kitchen in my homestay, I always went to the restaurant. Poor me üòÉ.

Here are few price range: (some places also add +10% then +5% for tax&services)

  • üçõ 20k/35k for a local Indonesian Warung (see pictures on the left) (1,2‚Ç¨ / 2,2‚Ç¨)
  • üç∫ 25k/30k for a 25cl local beer (Bintang). Add 10k (0,6‚Ç¨) for a big bottle. (1,6‚Ç¨ / 2,2‚Ç¨)
  • ‚òïÔ∏è 30k for a cup of coffee and 50k for a cup of Kopi Luwak coffee üí© (2,2‚Ç¨ / 3,1‚Ç¨)
  • üçç 40k/65k for a fruit salad/smoothie bowl (2,5‚Ç¨ / 4‚Ç¨)
  • üçï 60k/75k for a margarita pizza (3,7 / 4,7‚Ç¨)
  • üçî 90k/120k for a burger (5,6‚Ç¨ / 7,5‚Ç¨)

Most of the time I was eating in Indonesian Warung. Because I like to eat local, it‚Äôs very good and crazy cheap! If you don‚Äôt like rice, Bali might be a no-go for you! üòÑ

What to do in Canggu?

Canggu has definitely a lot to offer. I guess most of the tourist come here for surfing. Waves here are very good! And the other part of tourists come here for Yoga, although the Yoga scene is not the same as in Ubud.
If you want to relax, you can also go for a massage. I‚Äôve found the 1h Balinese massage very good üòÉ. A 1h massage will cost you around 120k (7‚Ç¨6). Outside Canggu, it even cheaper.

Tanah Lot ~ a nice temple very close to Canggu

You can also party. By night there‚Äôs a lot of drunk people in the streets. Mostly Australians. Few things you have to know:

  • fake alcoholis a thing here. They put methanol in a bottle and sell it for alcohol. In the best scenario, you will end up with a big headache. Worse scenario, you will die. Usually, Bintang (local beer) is a safe bet.
  • consuming drugs (including marijuana) is not allowed. In some country, you can do it because it‚Äôs not very risky. But here, it‚Äôs punishable by death. Now you know!

You can also move around Bali‚Ä¶ see the next part :)

Moving around

Here are a few things to visit if you are in Bali:

Ubud: Monkey Forest, Tegallalang Rice Terrace or visit few temples in the area. I‚Äôm actually writing this blog post from Ubud. That‚Äôs why I‚Äôm not talking too much about it‚Ä¶ I‚Äôll write another blog post for this town üôÇ

Amed: Diving or snorkelling! You can dive around the USS Liberty, a cargo ship torpedoed by a Japanese submarine during WWII. Life under the sea is breathtakingly beautiful. It‚Äôs also a good spot to access to the Gili Gili Island.

Ulun Danu Bratan Temple

Jatiluwih Rice Terraces (UNESCO World Heritages)

Bratan area: This area is great to see waterfalls. You have the well known Gitgit waterfall and also the Banyumala Twin Waterfalls (my favourites!). If you are in the area, go visit the Ulun Danu Bratan Temple! And then, finish with the Jatiluwih Rice Terraces (UNESCO World Heritages). I liked this area because it‚Äôs way less touristy than the other part of Bali.

Nusa Penida: Take a scooter and get lost in this paradisiac island. You have to go to Kelingking Beach. It‚Äôs probably the most beautiful beach I ever saw! Manta bay is also a good place for diving/snorkeling. Here, you can spot some manta ray, but take care of the loan!

Kelingking Beach ‚ù§Ô∏è

Nusa Lembongan and Nusa Ceningan: Two smalls islands close to Nusa Penisa (linked by a bridge). If you are there, take a scooter or just walk around the Island. There‚Äôs plenty of things to see like the Blue Lagoon. When you are there, take a drink at Mahana Point. In this bar, you will see the Devil‚Äôs Tears on the other island (waves are crashing on the cliffs). Once your drink is over, go to the other island to get closer to this Devil‚Äôs Tears. It‚Äôs very impressive! (it‚Äôs a good spot for sunsets!)

Transport

One thing I don‚Äôt like in Bali: it‚Äôs a scooter country! Usually, when I arrive in a city I take public transport or I walk. In Bali, there are no public transports. So, most of the time I walk (footpath are kinda dangerous).

For longer distances, a scooter is a must have. You can get one for 50-70k per day. If you don‚Äôt have an international licence with you, you might get arrested by the police. They will give you a 50 to 300k fine. It‚Äôs happened to me once‚Ä¶

If you don‚Äôt want to take this risk, you have 2 options: local taxis (aka taxi mafia) or online taxi (Gojek or Grab). Local taxis are literally scamming you with European prices. For this reason, I mostly use the application Gojek. It‚Äôs very cheap‚Ä¶and maybe too cheap: (don‚Äôt be a dick and give them a tip)

  • [üõµ scooter] 4k (~0.25‚Ç¨) for 5‚Äô (1.9km)
  • [üõµ scooter] 53k (~3.3‚Ç¨) for 1h
  • [üöï car] 229k (~14,3‚Ç¨) for 1h15 (36.2km)

Something good with these apps, they also deliver food!

Driving without a helmet is tolerated in Canggu. But you know, accidents happen, no matter how careful we are. Since I‚Äôm in Bali I heard many sad stories about driving accident, the last time was last week üò¢ Sorry to talk about sad things but it had to be said. If I want to rent a scooter (or take a taxi) and there‚Äôs no helmet, I consider it as a no go.

Money and Expenses

In Bali, most of the transactions are done by cash. When they accept a credit card, there is an additional 3% fee. Also, when you withdraw money, make sure to choose a reliable ATM. Card skimming is a thing here! Fortunately, I haven‚Äôt been skimmed (yet). ü§û

It the beginning, I thought Bali will be cheap. I don‚Äôt know how but, it turns out I spent more money in Canggu than in other European cities. Well, the fact that I didn‚Äôt have a kitchen helps a lot! If you want, here‚Äôs a detailed version of my expenses:

Per month
Rent640‚Ç¨
Food/Fun/Beers350‚Ç¨
Coworking space112‚Ç¨
Fun50‚Ç¨
Visa run ‚úàÔ∏è50‚Ç¨

Insurance30‚Ç¨

Laundry6‚Ç¨

Global feedback

Canggu deserves it #1 place on Nomad List. I really liked Canggu and the atmosphere! But, I have the feeling that Bali is becoming a victim of its own success.

  • üå§ Weather. I went there during the rainy season and it wasn‚Äôt raining that much. Once, I had a 12h of heavy rain! Otherwise, I had my ~30¬∞c every day.
  • üó£ Language. Because it‚Äôs a touristic place, (almost) everybody speaks English.
  • üç¥ Food. Awesome! (cf. Food section above) and the Bali Coffee is great too! (I‚Äôm not a big fan of Kopi Luwak‚Ä¶)
  • üåâ Size of the city. Canggu is very spread out city.
  • üö∂‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è Walkability. Very bad. I felt lucky when I found a sidewalk. And when you have one, you can‚Äôt
  • üì° Wi-Fi. Wifi is between OK and Bad. You can get a decent connection at Dojo (if it‚Äôs not crowded). The 4G works well, I had around 23MBPS (Telkomsel).
  • üëÆ‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è Safety. Bali is a very safe place. I felt quite safe. üêï Wild dogs are legion here
  • üíµ Prices. The biggest challenge for me was to avoid tourist traps. Otherwise it globally cheap. I spent ~1,300‚Ç¨ a month, but if you‚Äôre on a budget, you can live with less.

item.title: Enhance your git log with conventional commits
item.description: Git is a very powerful tool installed on most of our machines. As developer, we use it every day. But, unfortunately, at first glance, this tool is not very developer friendly. That's why a lot of people bypass the command line interface (CLI) with a‚Ä¶
item.content:encoded:
Git is a very powerful tool installed on most of our machines. As developer, we use it every day. But, unfortunately, at first glance, this tool is not very developer friendly. That‚Äôs why a lot of people bypass the command line interface (CLI) with a graphical user interface (GUI).
It‚Äôs like using a framework without knowing the language itself. It can be OK at the beginning but, sooner or later you, you will have problems.

Let‚Äôs take an example:

$ git log --oneline ./src/components/button/

daccff1f test should pass
3fff19f6 test should pass
5b998d9a add disabled property for button
06faab4d fix lint
186cce90 refactor button
4b99d91a fix spinner component
5b998d9a fix css
263288a5 test should pass
c3fb85af Create Button component

There‚Äôs might be nothing wrong for you with this log. Let me show you the issues I‚Äôve found with this log:

  • It‚Äôs hard to understand the Component‚Äôs history. We might repeat errors already fixed.
  • There are unnecessary commits which pollute logs and make history hard to read. Also, functionalities like git blame become irrelevant.
  • It seems that a feature was added by a few commits. Which commit should I include if I want to revert this operation?
  • 4b99d9a say something about a different component. Is it an unwanted change? Again, what if we need to revert?
  • ‚Ä¶

I think we shouldn‚Äôt confound git commit with ctrl + s. A git log should be like reading a story. By reading the log, I should be able to understand in ~10s the whole file history.

What if we had something like this:

$ git log --oneline ./src/components/button/

06faab4d revert: feat: add disabled property
186cce90 feat: add disabled property
5b998d9a test: add scenario for readonly property
263288a5 fix: fix css when hover
c3fb85af feat: add button component

Way cleaner, isn‚Äôt it? That something called Conventional Commits.

Conventional commits

Conventional commits is a Git commit convention made by the Angular team. Basically, every pull request should end up with one commit and a standardized commit message.

The message should follow this regex:

/^(revert: )?(feat|fix|docs|style|refactor|perf|test|chore)(\(.+\))?: .{1,50}/

Types of commit:

  • feat: Add a new feature (equivalent to a MINOR in Semantic Versioning).
  • fix: Fix a bug (equivalent to a PATCH in Semantic Versioning).
  • docs: Documentation changes.
  • style: Code style change (semicolon, indentation‚Ä¶).
  • refactor: Refactor code without changing public API.
  • perf: Update code performances.
  • test: Add test to an existing feature.
  • chore: Update something without impacting the user (ex: bump a dependency in package.json).

Project that uses this convention: Angular, Vue.js, Gatsby (almost), Lerna (almost), jest (almost).

Benefits

Project/code understandability
Commits are more descriptives and it‚Äôs easier to understand the project‚Äôs history. It became also easier and to contribute.
For example, I never contributed to the Angular‚Äôs http package. But, reading the repo‚Äôs git log helps me to better understand this package‚Äôs history.

Usability
If you have one action per commit, it became easier to revert a change. Same if you have git conflict‚Ä¶

Master your Git skills
Because not all Git-repository manager have a ‚Äúsquash and merge‚Äù option, you sometimes have to do this operation by yourself. So, you will learn how to ‚Äúsquash‚Äù your commits, how to ‚Äúfixup‚Äù a commit, how to remove a specific commit‚Ä¶ It‚Äôs always important to know what‚Äôs going on under the hood!

See also

  • conventionalcommits.org
  • Vue.js commit convention
  • github.com/conventional-changelog/conventional-changelog - A nice tool to generate changelog based on the git message.
  • github.com/conventional-changelog/commitlint - A git commit linter. Use it with Husky.

item.title: 2018 - A Year In Review
item.description: Disclaimer: I mostly wrote this blog post for myself. Writing my Year in review helps me to celebrate my biggest wins, see what was wrong and define goals for the upcoming year. 2018 was a whirlwind year full of a lot of great opportunities and‚Ä¶
item.content:encoded:
Disclaimer: I mostly wrote this blog post for myself. Writing my Year in review helps me to celebrate my biggest wins, see what was wrong and define goals for the upcoming year.

2018 was a whirlwind year full of a lot of great opportunities and travel.

üë®üèº‚Äçüíª Work

In April, I left HostelWorld. I stayed 18 months there, which is longer than most of my friends though! I loved to work with people from everywhere in the world. But, I felt overwhelmed by politics decisions. Plus, my team and I weren‚Äôt really challenged.

In May, joined VSware in Dublin as a Senior Frontend Engineer. In a nutshell, the company is doing a cloud-based solution for schools (currently focusing on the Norwegian market). Here are few insights from what changed for me:

  • I switched from a PHP/JavaScript position to a 100% JavaScript position. This is exactly what I wanted!
  • I work on a day to day with a very large Vue.js application.
  • I have the ability to work remotely.

Since October, I‚Äôm 100% remote! üò±

üéí New remote/nomadic life

Going full-time remote was probably one of the biggest change for me in 2018. Now, every place in the world with a table and a decent WIFI is a potential office for me. Surprisingly, I found myself comfortable to work from anywhere. It can be at home, in a cafe or, in a coworking space.
Hey, since you‚Äôre here: forget about the long chair on the beach, except if you want to break your back or show off on Instagram.

Before/after ~ no more 24‚Äô curved screen! But, I‚Äôm now more focus with only one screen!

To make this shift successful, I set up some rules to avoid procrastination and get a healthy work-life balance:

  • Don‚Äôt fall into the temptation of working from bed;
  • If I can‚Äôt work, stop pretending to work. Do it later;
  • Communicate, communicate, communicate. Communication is the key!
  • Every day, I write down my MIT (Most Important Thing) to keep focus and avoid distractions;
  • No overwork;
  • Come back to the office every now and then to say ‚Äúhello‚Äù.

I‚Äôve found a big difference between full-time remote and part-time remote. You can‚Äôt postpone a meeting because you‚Äôre in the office next week and it‚Äôs more convenient‚Ä¶

üë®üèº‚Äçüî¨ Sides Projects

I wasn‚Äôt a very prolific author in 2018. I only blogged 3 times! The main reason (after laziness), was my platform. Jekyll started to be too heavy to me. So, I moved my personal website to Gatsby. Working with this tool is pure pleasure. Hot reload, performances, fancy technologies‚Ä¶ I don‚Äôt regret it at all!
Another important thing for me: I decided to release the template to the community. It was a good idea because it seems that other people enjoy using it üíú

In 2017 I had a total of 36,546 pages view on my website. In 2018, I blogged less and I reached 64,700 pages view! There are a few reasons:

  • Gatsby made my website more SEO friendly;
  • I also posted my posts on Reddit. The community here is great, I had really good feedback!
  • I cross-posted blog the Vue.js article on Dev.to platform. With only 2 posts, I have more followers on Dev.to (~400) than Twitter (~280) ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è

Also, docker-symfony reached 1 000 ‚≠êÔ∏è on GitHub! Yay! Unfortunately, I can‚Äôt maintain it since I stopped using PHP.

üó£ Conference

I spoke 6 times about 2 different topics: Progressive Web Apps (PWA) and Frontend Testing. For the first time, I delivered talks outside France or Ireland! I had the opportunity to speak in 4 different countries: Ireland, Austria, Poland and Spain. Yes, no conference in France for 2018!

Also, I gave my very first workshop! It was an introduction to Vue.js at @DublinJS.

A funny anecdote: during my talk at Voxxed Vienna, I showed -by mistake- all my GitHub Recovery Codes + Personal access token ü§¶‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è

‚úàÔ∏è Travel

My 2018 trips on a map!

This year, I travelled a LOT! I did 9 countries and 14 cities! For the first time in my life, I went outside Europe. In January, I visit the US: Los Angeles and San Francisco. 4 months later, I visited Canada: Toronto, Quebec City and Montreal!

Since I‚Äôve got a NomadList profile, I can now track my trips like a pro!

‚ú® Random stuff

  • üçÄ Farewell Dublin. as you guess, I left Ireland after 2 years living as an expat. Apart from the chaotic housing situation, I still really like this country. And I don‚Äôt exclude to come back!
  • üéí Minimalism. After watching The Minimalist (available on Netflix) and Matt D‚ÄôAvella‚Äôs podcast, I decided to try this way of life. Now, all my clothes, electronics‚Ä¶ fit in a backpack. The only thing I miss is my Xbox!
  • ü•ó Eat better. This year I also started eating better: more vegetables and fruits and less meat/fish. But, I didn‚Äôt become a vegan or a vegetarian (and I don‚Äôt want to be).
  • üìï Readings. According to my Pocket stats, I‚Äôve read the equivalent of 7 books. But I think I‚Äôve read much more since I didn‚Äôt use this app for months.

Previous goals

  • ‚úÖ Get a new job
  • üòê Continue to give talks. I gave a few talks this year. But not as much as I wanted to.
  • ‚úÖ Give talks in other countries than France & Ireland. Vienna (Austria), Krakow (Poland) and Madrid (Spain)
  • ‚úÖ Switch to a frontend position.
  • üòê ~ ‚úÖ Travel 1 country / month. I think this goal was a bit unrealistic. But, I‚Äôm happy with what I did!
  • üòê Keep blogging. Only 3 blog post this year!
  • üòê Sport. No gym for me in 2018! After, I used to walk 1-2h/day.

High-level 2019 goals

In 2019, I‚Äôm going to work from Asia, I have a few goals attached to this trip.

  • [Asia trip] Be able to work with my Irish colleagues;
  • [Asia trip] Be grateful. Having the ability to work from the other side of the globe is a great opportunity.
  • [Asia trip] Enjoy my trip!
  • Make more relevant/valuable side project;
  • Give Miracle Morning another try;
  • Write blog posts (let say 6 and one in French);
  • Dry January - one month without alcohol or anything else‚Ä¶
  • Give meditation another try;
  • Continue to give talks & workshops;
  • Reach 500 followers on Twitter. Nah I‚Äôm jocking. Getting more followers is everything but not a priority for me!
  • Write my 2019 year in review on time! üôÉ

As you can see, 2018 was a great year for me. I can‚Äôt wait to see what 2019 has in store!

item.title: 3 Tips for Scaling Large Vue.js Application
item.description: TLDR; Split your application into completely isolated modules Consider micro-frontends architecture Don't overuse your Vuex store Tip #1: Think Module! The file architecture given by vue-cli is great. But after 3-4 pages, your files will start‚Ä¶
item.content:encoded:
TLDR;

  • Split your application into completely isolated modules
  • Consider micro-frontends architecture
  • Don‚Äôt overuse your Vuex store

Tip #1: Think Module!

The file architecture given by vue-cli is great. But after 3-4 pages, your files will start to become overweight. You might be tempted to put separate your components into multiple folders. But, again, after 10 pages, you will face the same issue again.

The idea is to split your application by notions. Stick to one unique word. For example, in a shop application, we could get Catalog, Basket and Payment.

‚îú‚îÄ src/
‚îÇ  ‚îú‚îÄ core/
‚îÇ  ‚îú‚îÄ modules/
‚îÇ  ‚îÇ  ‚îú‚îÄ Catalog/
‚îÇ  ‚îÇ  ‚îÇ  ‚îú‚îÄ Components/
‚îÇ  ‚îÇ  ‚îÇ  ‚îú‚îÄ Pages/
‚îÇ  ‚îÇ  ‚îÇ  ‚îú‚îÄ Routes/
‚îÇ  ‚îÇ  ‚îÇ  ‚îú‚îÄ Services/
‚îÇ  ‚îÇ  ‚îÇ  ‚îÇ  ‚îú‚îÄ catalog.api.js
‚îÇ  ‚îÇ  ‚îÇ  ‚îÇ  ‚îî‚îÄ catalog.services.js
‚îÇ  ‚îÇ  ‚îÇ  ‚îú‚îÄ Store/
‚îÇ  ‚îÇ  ‚îÇ  ‚îÇ  ‚îú‚îÄ catalog.action.js
‚îÇ  ‚îÇ  ‚îÇ  ‚îÇ  ‚îî‚îÄ catalog.getters.js
‚îÇ  ‚îÇ  ‚îÇ  ‚îÇ  ‚îî‚îÄ catalog.mutationTypes.js
‚îÇ  ‚îÇ  ‚îÇ  ‚îÇ  ‚îî‚îÄ catalog.state.js
‚îÇ  ‚îÇ  ‚îÇ  ‚îÇ  ‚îî‚îÄ index.js
‚îÇ  ‚îÇ  ‚îÇ  ‚îú‚îÄ Tests/
‚îÇ  ‚îÇ  ‚îÇ  ‚îú‚îÄ Catalog.vue

Few important things here:

Isolation

To keep a good isolation, modules should not between them. What I mean is, Module A shouldn‚Äôt share a component with Module B. For common functionalities (i.e. user logged in, user language‚Ä¶), you have the core folder!

Smart vs. Dumb components

It is important to keep a separation between your smart components (Pages folder) from the dumbs (Components folder). In a nutshell:

  • smart components: can access the store, router, window object‚Ä¶
  • dumbs components: take props, emits events. That‚Äôs it!

The main benefits of this approach are reusability, a better separation of concerns‚Ä¶

Split, split, split!

If your component is getting too big, don‚Äôt be shy: split it! In the Vue.js‚Äôs guide, the ‚ÄúTightly coupled component names‚Äù rule is considered as Strongly Recommended.

// üëé Bad
|- TodoList.vue
|- TodoItem.vue
|- TodoButton.vue

// üëç Good
|- CatalogList.vue
|- CatalogListItem.vue
|- CatalogListItemButton.vue

Isolate styles too!

Remember: Global CSS are evil. Avoid them as much as you can!

  • .vue files: the easier quick win for that is to use the scoped attribute in the style tag: <styles scoped>

  • Not a big fan of .vue files? (if you want to create multiple small components without creating dozen of files). Consider libraries such as üíÖ vue-styled-components. The style encapsulation works like a charm!

    import styled from 'vue-styled-components'

const StyledTitle = styled.h1`
  font-size: 1.5em;
  text-align: center;
  color: palevioletred;
`

;<StyledTitle>Cool title</StyledTitle>

Testing

Testing application is a very complex topic, who deserves an entire blog post. To keep it simple, let‚Äôs take the previous file architecture and see what to test and how to do it.

  • Components: Low priority, easy to do. write unit tests for each component. It should be easy to do.
  • Pages: High priority, hard to do. You probably gonna have to mock api/browser parts.
  • Routes: Usually bugs aren‚Äôt here. Leave it for E2E tests.
  • Services:
    • api interface: I personnally don‚Äôt test this part (90% of the code is mocked).
    • helpers/dataFormaters: High priority, easy to do. Usually, the easiest tests to do in your app!
  • Store: The hardest part to test. You can test it via integration tests. Testing action, getter and initial state separately is useless.

üí° Lazy load your modules!

To reduce the JavaScript bundle, consider lazy load your modules!

export default new Router({
  routes: [
    {
      path: '/catalog',
      name: 'catalog',
      component: () => import(/* webpackChunkName: "catalog" */ './modules/Catalog/views/Catalog.vue')    },
    // ...
  ]
})

If you already did this and you still think that your app is too big, you might consider the next tip.

Tip #2: Consider micro-frontends

Over the last years, microservices architecture had become quite trendy. A lot of companies splitted their plain old monolith backend into a lot of small services on the backend.

Today, it seems that some companies had copy this backend paradigm into frontend world. The promise is quite similar to the backend: split big monolith into multiple applications, scale and be able to write application with different technologies. Yes. You correctly read the last sentence. You can write the payment application in Vue and the Catalog application in React.

If needed, different applications can talk together through events registered on the window object (observer publish/subscribe).

‚ö†Ô∏è But I give you a warning. There‚Äôs no silver bullet. When you leave a paradigm for another one, you don‚Äôt get rid of the problems. You replace them.

üëç Pros: complete isolation

If the backend is also micro-service oriented, teams can work in silos. They control their domain from end-to-end.

üëç Pros: ability to use different frameworks / different version of one framework

Let say team working on the Catalog want to update to the next version of Vue. Unfortunatelly, the team who‚Äôs working on the payment isn‚Äôt ready yet. They have to deliver a big feature before and would be ready in 3 months. When the application is separated into multiple small applications, they‚Äôre completely independents. They can bump version of one library or one framework without impacting any other team.

Also, if another team want to start a new sub-application, they can use the technology they want without impacting everybody.¬ß

üëç Pros: independent deployments

This is probably the biggest advantage. ‚ÄúTeam Catalog‚Äù can work and release independently from ‚ÄúTeam Payment‚Äù.

ü§î Cons: design system integration

If you have a Design System written in Vue, you probably don‚Äôt want to rewrite it in React just because one team want to experiment something. In this case, you might be interested in Web Components. From my experience, it‚Äôs great. But when you do some, it‚Äôs another story. Plus it‚Äôs not supported by IE11 (polyfills are needed).

üí° Tip: You can generate Web Components with vue-cli and this command:

vue-cli-service build --target wc --name foo 'src/components/*.vue'

ü§î Cons: aligning teams is hard

If you‚Äôre still working on a plain old monolith, it‚Äôs gonna be a very long journey to get there. Also, if the backend is not already in a micro-service architecture, you can‚Äôt work in completely isolated silos. Maybe the Frontend team will be independant, but the back will not.

ü§î Cons: performances

When you modularise your app, each module can be splitted into chunks (via tools like WebPack 4). You load the main dependencies once, then when you load the Payment page, the code is loaded. If you convert existing modules to separated/isolated application, then the main framework on each application will be loaded on each module.

ü§î Cons: routing

To go from Module A to module B, Module A need to know the full path. A common thing is to hard code the URI. After all: ‚ÄúCool URIs don‚Äôt change‚Äù (W3C)

‚ö†Ô∏è Avoid Hype Driven Development‚Ñ¢Ô∏è. You probably don‚Äôt need this architecture yet. Only consider Micro-frontend architecture if you think that you reached the limit of modularisation!

Tip #3: Be kind with your store (Vuex)

One of the biggest problems with a component-based application is the store. At first glance, it looks amazing. The first time I saw the vue tools, it completely blew my mind. I started using it everywhere! Then, problems start arriving.

  • 20 mutations when a page load (makes time travel impossible);
  • open a page, do something, go to another page and come back. The state isn‚Äôt reinitialized;
  • overkilled features. You need to create mutation for everything.

Here are few tips to keep your store maintainable.

Don‚Äôt overuse the store

There are a lot of misconceptions about the store. I don‚Äôt know why, but many people think that: ‚ÄúVue is to manage the UI and Vuex is to manage application state‚Äù. I strongly disagree with this. Based on my experience, moving all the logic in the store lead to overhead and unnecessary complex features. Also, more code === to more surface area for bugs.

Usually, when we have existential questions like this, we turn to the creators.

It‚Äôs not mandatory, nor recommended putting all your state inside a Vuex store.
‚Äî Evan You (creator of Vue.js)

I also put another quote from Dan Abramov, mostly because Vuex is partialy inspired by Redux. Also, component oriented application have a lot of point of interest.

Use React for ephemeral state that doesn‚Äôt matter to the app globally and doesn‚Äôt mutate in complex ways. For example, a toggle in some UI element, a form input state. Use Redux for state that matters globally or is mutated in complex ways. For example, cached users, or a post draft.
‚Äî Dan Abramov (creator of redux, equivalent of Vuex but for React)

When I ask to myself: ‚Äúshould I use the store or not?‚Äù, I usually do something like that in my mind:

In other terms, here are few examples:

  • Store ‚ÄúCurrent user, i18n preferences‚Äù ‚Üí Yes.
  • ‚ÄúData loaded via API call‚Äù ‚Üí Joker! Do the less awkward. I usually keep it in the component‚Äôs state. I agree that sometimes, it makes sense to share this data with the rest of the app.
  • State related to an edit/creation form ‚Üí No.
  • ‚ÄúToggle a UI element‚Äù ‚Üí No.
  • ‚ÄúManage a isLoading state‚Äù ‚Üí No.

I‚Äôm not saying that you shouldn‚Äôt use the store. Just use it with parsimony!

Use namespaced stores (for modules)

const store = new Vuex.Store({
  modules: {
    catalog: {
      namespaced: true,      state,
      getters: {
        getFeaturedProducts () { ... } // -> getters['catalog/getFeaturedProducts']      },
    }
  }
})

Don‚Äôt writte simplistic getters.

To be relevant, a getter must contain some logic. If you want to access to a subproperty, prefer mapState.

getters: {
  // ü§î non useful getter
  getProducts: state => state.products,
  // üëç useful getter
  getFeaturedProducts: state => state.products.filter(p => p.isFeatured),
}

item.title: My first month in Lisbon as a Digital Nomad
item.description: After 2 years, I decided to leave Dublin. I'm still working for the same company but 100% remote. When it comes to finding a "nomadic friendly" city, usually Nomad List is the site to go. I put a few parameters: Europe and good weather (I needed it‚Ä¶
item.content:encoded:
After 2 years, I decided to leave Dublin. I‚Äôm still working for the same company but 100% remote. When it comes to finding a ‚Äúnomadic friendly‚Äù city, usually Nomad List is the site to go. I put a few parameters: Europe and good weather (I needed it!).

As you can see, Lisbon appear in the first position. Plus, I heard good things about this city. That‚Äôs 2 good reasons to give a try!

Accommodation

My plan was to stay a month in Lisbon. For short term stay, the best option remains Airbnb. In Lisbon, you can get something decent from 20 to 50‚Ç¨/night (depends on your expectations). If you stay longer, you should probably take a look at some dedicated Facebook groups.

Meeting people

The expat and digital communities here are very active. If you want to, you can find something every day and not only in the evening!

Meetup.com lists most of the events are. If I had to select just two, it would be Lisbon Expats & Locals and Lisbon Digital Nomads. Also, I‚Äôve found this Facebook group (Lisbon Digital Nomads) very interesting. Mostly if you want to get some tips from other nomads.

Good places to work from

One thing that really surprised me, is the very strong caf√© culture in the city. It‚Äôs very frequent to find people working I usually stay 3-4h / place. If you plan to get there, I recommend you this places!

Linha D‚ÄôAgua

  • ü§ó Amazing view!
  • üëé Unsympathetic staff
  • üîå Power outlet: few
  • üåê Network: ok

Choupana

  • ü§ó Amazing staff, a lot of pastries. Prices are ok.
  • üîå Power outlet: Almost no one
  • üåê Network: ok

Galveias Palace (Library) - There is also a cafe outside in the yard. I spent a lot of time in this coffee!

  • üëç Quiet atmosphere, very cheap
  • üîå Almost a lot (in Library)
  • üåê Network: bad. Like very bad!

Wish Coffee - Located in Lx Factory, an old industrial complex.

  • üëç Well placed.
  • ‚ö†Ô∏è No laptop sticker on tables. I came in the morning and it was ok for me to work there for a few hours. A bit more expensive than other (2‚Ç¨ for a coffee when the average is 0.7-1‚Ç¨).
  • üîå Power outlet: few
  • üåê Network: ok

Ler Devagar - Next to Wish Coffee. It‚Äôs actually a bookshop but there‚Äôs a lot of tables and a cafe downstairs.

  • üëç Well placed. The decoration is super nice.
  • ‚ö†Ô∏è Can be noisy (visitors). Also, it‚Äôs allowed to smoke inside üò©
  • üîå Power outlet: many
  • üåê Network: ok

Evolution Hotel

  • üëç Nice sofa, excellent staff!
  • üîå Power outlet: many
  • üåê Network: good

Mobile application

(Android but I believe they are also on OS)

  • Foursquare. Say where you are and what you‚Äôre looking for (coffee, things to do in the city), and the app will find it for you! I‚Äôve found user review more accurate than other applications.
  • Meetup.com.
  • WifiMap. Show a map of the city with all Wi-Fi access and passwords. It was very helpful. For example, one day I‚Äôve found a very nice coffee but the internet connection was very slow. Thank to this app, I‚Äôve found a better network. Only cons, it contains few adds.

My feedback about Lisbon

My feedback about Lisbon is very positive. I really liked this city and I met very good people there! I will definitely come back!

  • üå§ Weather. I still remember the pilot saying: ‚ÄúWelcome to Lisbon [‚Ä¶] temperature is 27¬∞c‚Äù‚Ä¶in October! Usually, in Winter, it gets around 10-15¬∞c and around 30¬∞c in Summer.
  • üó£ Language. The language barrier wasn‚Äôt very strong. Most of the people there speak with very good English.
  • üë®üèº‚Äçüíª Nomad friendly. As I said in the coffee section above, there are a lot of coffee places to work from. Despite the fact that I didn‚Äôt use coworking spaces at all, there are everywhere in the city. When I come back, I‚Äôd love one day to try some fancy ones like Second Home :)
  • üç¥ Food. In general, good is good and cheap! Especially the seafood! I really miss the Pastel de Nata with my coffee!
  • üåâ Size of the city. For me, it‚Äôs a perfect size: not too big, not too small. Be careful, Lisbon can be hilly sometimes!
  • üöã Transports. Because the city is very walkable, I didn‚Äôt really use them. But if you‚Äôre in a lazy mood, there‚Äôs always a way to get somewhere by public transport (bus/metro).
  • üö∂‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è Exploration. Lisbon offers a wide range of parks. Once you start getting comfortable with the city, you can take a train and visit the neighbourhood. You have several options: Sintra, Belem (you can skip the tower)‚Ä¶
  • üì° Wi-Fi. Overall it‚Äôs great!
  • üëÆ‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è Safety. I‚Äôve found the city very safe. However, I heard stories about pick-pockets in the touristic city centre.
  • üíµ Prices. I think this city is a victim of its own success. Years ago, this city was very cheap so, a lot of people moved there. Now prices are still very decent but it‚Äôs getting unaffordable for locals. I heard a lot of complaints from locals. Apart from that, a coffee is around 1‚Ç¨ and a beer around 1-3‚Ç¨. You can eat for 5-10‚Ç¨ or more if you want something fancier.
